Award.AwardTitle: Thermodynamics and Physical Properties of selected Heusler Alloys
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
Heusler compounds of type X2YZ and half-Heusler compounds of type XYZ, where X and Y are transition metals and Z is a group III-V element, can exhibit interesting and useful properties, such as shape memory, thermoelectric, ferromagnetic and spin polarization effects. Unexplored compounds of these types could lead to new mechanical and electronic devices. The thermodynamic properties, crystal structures and phase equilibria of a large number of these compounds will be systematically determined. Drop calorimetry will be used to measure the standard heat of formation and heat capacity as a function of temperature. Phase equilibria and crystal structures will be determined using differential scanning calorimetry, energy dispersive X-ray analysis and X-ray diffraction. The thousands of possible compositions will be rapidly screened using systematic analyses of phase diagrams and first-principles calculations to identify specific systems for study. The thermodynamic data obtained will be incorporated into an on-line database for access by the scientific community. The data will be used to predict phase equilibria and to benchmark first principles calculations for these compounds. Students from high school through graduate school will be trained through these investigations.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The Heusler family of alloys holds promise for the next generation of sensors and actuators. This experimental study will produce thermodynamic data of fundamental importance to the exploration and future development of these promising materials. Properties to be measured include both thermodynamic and physical properties. Collaborations with scientists around the world will enable computational screening of thousands of potential compositions to determine those most appropriate for experiments and will enable the measurement of potentially useful physical properties. The data produced, which are expected to be critical to the field for future material development and benchmarking/validation of computational predictions, will be made available through a free on-line database. Education and training activities will include graduate students, undergraduate students and high-school students. Outreach will include the construction and dissemination of video tutorials on experimental techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved the determination of thermodynamic, phase equilibria and crystallographic data for binary and ternary intermetallic compounds. The results of this project provide the basic data necessary fro alloy development of this important class of materials. Intermetallic compounds are useful both in structural and functional applications. A major focus of this project was on determining properties of Heusler intermetallic compounds. The Heusler compounds have many interesting properties that make them of value as actuators, magnets, energy convertors and new types of electronic components based on spintronics. In order to utilize such compounds it is necessary to know basic thermodynamic information such as the heat of formation of the compound as determined in this work. These data are used in models to predict the behavior of the compound and its relationship to related phases which may be used to produce multi-functional materials. The data are also used to test the validity of first principles calculations and thermodynamic based calculations of material properties. The data produced in this project form an important part of the Materials Genome effort to provide the basis for future accelerated development of materials.

 

The project has involved a number scientists at different stages of their careers. Six high school students undertook their student research projects working on this project. Two PhD students and one MS student have been trained to perform the experiments and data analysis during this award and a number of journal manuscripts have been published. The work has involved international collaboration with colleagues in Austria, China, and the Czech Republic.  The work has been disseminated to colleagues through presentations at meetings and through our publicly accessible thermodynamic database of experimental heats of formation. The PI also provides instruction in the calorimeter laboratory on the experimental techniques used in this project for the undergraduate students in his thermodynamics course. We have developed the techniques for constructing the Kleppa type calorimeter so that the necessary expertise for constructing future calorimeters is in house.
